text: Seems like a lot of people are trading horses/dogs, i'm guessing there are more arb opportunities there?

text:
Horses and dogs are good because there’s a lot of them and a lot of liquidity every single day of the year so a good basis for building a staple. At least that’s why I initially chose it. 

It also has mostly smooth continuous movement in odds rather than being governed by discrete events like goals or sets which helps to make strategy returns less volatile. There’s obviously a lot more pre-event movement than in the other sports too. 

But in terms of how much you can win, I expect it’s of the same magnitude as any of the other big sports.

elements.text: Horses and dogs are good because there’s a lot of them and a lot of liquidity every single day of the year so a good basis for building a staple. At least that’s why I initially chose it.

But in terms of how much you can win, I expect it’s of the same magnitude as any of the other big sports.

text: Yeah, you can look at the exchanges (Betfair/Betdaq/Smarkets) as the “trading venues”. But Betfair is the only real viable one for scale which keeps it simple.

text: In terms of strategy sensitivity to latency it really depends on the strategy. I would expect something fundamental based to be less sensitive to arbitrage for example. I would class what I do as statistical arbitrage, and I’m sensitive to around 100ms when betting pre-race. ie. I can notice lower returns with an extra delay of 100ms. 1ms not.

elements.text: In terms of strategy sensitivity to latency it really depends on the strategy. I would expect something fundamental based to be less sensitive to arbitrage for example. I would class what I do as statistical arbitrage, and I’m sensitive to around 100ms when betting pre-race. ie. I can notice lower returns with an extra delay of 100ms. 1ms not.

text:
This is all down to backtesting though. Not live split testing. 

So that’s another good use for a backtesting system like flumine. You can adjust your simulated latency and see what effect that has on returns.

elements.text: This is all down to backtesting though. Not live split testing.
So that’s another good use for a backtesting system like flumine. You can adjust your simulated latency and see what effect that has on returns.

text:
Backtesting does have its caveats though, as much as I advocate it. You can’t account for market impact or how the market will react to your bets. And that can be enough to kill a live strategy compared to its backtest. 

eg. If you offer, you can’t know if someone will undercut you. If you take, you don’t know how the book will react (potentially further down the line). 

I know <@U4H19D1D2> had some great ideas on measuring market impact. I’m hoping he’ll include a page on that too when he has time!

elements.text: Backtesting does have its caveats though, as much as I advocate it. You can’t account for market impact or how the market will react to your bets. And that can be enough to kill a live strategy compared to its backtest.

text:
I think you have two choices re: getting started and setting your future path in terms of implementation. 

You can either learn Python and use the libraries provided by the great community here. 

Or you stick with a language you’re already experienced in and use existing code or Betfair sample applications. But then build a data collection and backtesting platform yourself.

elements.text: I think you have two choices re: getting started and setting your future path in terms of implementation.
You can either learn Python and use the libraries provided by the great community here.
Or you stick with a language you’re already experienced in and use existing code or Betfair sample applications. But then build a data collection and backtesting platform yourself.

text:
Machine learning doesn't really seem to add that much of an edge at the moment (mostly speaking from the finance side but I assume it's pretty much the same in sports betting, if not even more so). You'd probably be able to get most information you need just using simple linear regressions.

If you really want to learn some ML, I would suggest taking one of those intro courses on Udemy (when there's a sale on ofc). They can give you a decent introduction to a topic in relatively small amounts of time, at least in my experience.

elements.text:
Machine learning doesn't really seem to add that much of an edge at the moment (mostly speaking from the finance side but I assume it's pretty much the same in sports betting, if not even more so). You'd probably be able to get most information you need just using simple linear regressions.

If you really want to learn some ML, I would suggest taking one of those intro courses on Udemy (when there's a sale on ofc). They can give you a decent introduction to a topic in relatively small amounts of time, at least in my experience.

elements.text: ML does work and there are those (some on here) that make silly sums, Mo is just saying that you don’t need it

text: Oh really?

elements.text: Oh really?

text: I figured the use of it was pretty limited in sports trading - my assumption being that there's a very low signal/noise ratio and coming from a more short-term price prediction point of view

elements.text: I figured the use of it was pretty limited in sports trading - my assumption being that there's a very low signal/noise ratio and coming from a more short-term price prediction point of view

text:
Yeah, I see ML more as a tool. It’s not really an edge in itself, but you can apply it ways that other methods wouldn’t be feasible. You can make or not make money with or without ML. The edge is in how you apply it. 

But if you’re starting out, ML is inherently complex and can be a bit of a black box. So I’d advise avoiding that added complexity at the beginning. Start simple and build up.

elements.text: Yeah, I see ML more as a tool. It’s not really an edge in itself, but you can apply it ways that other methods wouldn’t be feasible. You can make or not make money with or without ML. The edge is in how you apply it.
But if you’re starting out, ML is inherently complex and can be a bit of a black box. So I’d advise avoiding that added complexity at the beginning. Start simple and build up.

text: I'd love to know how much 'silly' is

elements.text: I'd love to know how much 'silly' is

text:
ML can certainly lead down long pathways that eventually get to nothing! I’ve been there! So not worth risking that time at the start in my opinion. But it’s all a learning process obviously. A lot of my dead ends have resulted in knowledge I’ve used later on (even though it was painful at the time!). 

So time is rarely completely wasted I suppose. That’s just a bit of encouragement for the people who think this whole betting lark is like hitting your head against a brick wall :joy:

text:
Slightly tongue in cheek obviously. But you’re on the right path. Do lots of work in your spare time, hopefully build a side income, then go professional once you’re confident. Either that, or with enough experience get a job related to it. 

I remember when I was still in the office day job I would use annual leave to stay home and program! I didn’t tell colleagues that obviously. They would have thought I was crazy. I just said “nah, didn’t go anywhere, just wanted a holiday to chill out” :joy:
